commit_message:
Cyborg/Nova/Glance interaction in compute node, including os-acc.

Change-Id: I246f8c70cbdcd4ef7d1b78119eb68b8a5cfa63bb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cyborg refs/changes/38/577438/13 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Cyborg is an OpenStack project that aims to provide a general purpose management framework for accelerators, such as FPGAs and GPUs. For scheduling an instance that needs accelerators, Cyborg shall work with Nova in three areas: as resource classes and devices as resource providers in Placement. When a device is discovered, Cyborg shall update resource inventories for those providers in Placement. * Instance placement/scheduling: In the controller node, Cyborg *may* provide a weigher that prioritizes hosts based on available accelerator resources. * Attachment of accelerators to instances: In the compute node, Cyborg shall interact with Nova through a library named os-acc, analogous to os-vif (for Neutron) and os-brick (for Cinder). The behavior with respect to accelerators for various instance operations (like start, pause and reboot) needs to be defined explicitly. For FPGAs, the interaction with Glance for programming needs to be laid out.addresses the third. Specifically: * It defines the behavior with respect to accelerators for various instance operations (such as start, pause and reboot). This specifies the situations when Nova must invoke os-acc to attach/detach accelerators. * It defines the structure of os-acc. It also defines the Virtual Accelerator Nexus (VAN), the handle object representing a means by which an accelerator can be attached to an instance (VM, container or process). * It defines the end-to-end workflow for creation and placement of instances with accelerators. * For FPGAs, Cyborg also needs to interact with Glance for fetching bitstreams. Some aspects of that are covered in [#BitstreamSpec]_. This spec will address the interaction of Cyborg and Glance in the compute node. This spec represents an update to the earlier Compute Node spec [#ComputeNodeSpec]_.* Virtual Accelerator Nexus (VAN): A handle object representing a means by which an accelerator can be attached to a VM, container or process. It may be based on PCI functions (PCI VF with SR-IOV), mediated devices, Power architecture DRC Index (or location code or the like). accelerators in a region:: +-------------------+ +--------+ | VM 0 | | VM 1 | +-------------------+ +--------+ +--------+ +--------+ +--------+ | VAN-0 | | VAN-1 +<---+ | VAN-N | +------+-+ +--------+ | +------+-+ ^ | ^ +------|-----------------|--------------------------|-----+ | | | | | | +---|-----------------|---+ +------|--+ | | | + + | | + | | | | ACC0 ACC1 ACC2 ACC3 | | ACC0 | | | | | | | | | | | +---------+ | | | ACC4 ACC5 ACC6 ACC7 | | | | | | | +-------------------------+ | | Device | +---------------------------------------------------------+============================= Cyborg in Rocky. In general, when accelerators are detached from an instance, the associated resources are released. So, if the instance could be restarted after a disruptive operation, either the accelerators should not be detached or the instance must get rescheduled on restart. The list of supported operations (with the intended behaviors) are as follows: * When an instance is started, the accelerators requested by that instance's flavor must be attached to the instance. On deletion, those resources are released. * When an instance is stopped, paused, suspended or locked, the accelerator resources are left intact, and not detached from the instance. So, when the instance is restarted, unpaused, resumed or unlocked, there is nothing to do.* Rebuild: Prior to the instance image replacement, all device access must be quiesced, i.e., accesses to devices from that instance must be completed and further accesses must be prohibited. The mechanics of such quiescing are outside the scope of this document. With that precondition, accelerator resources are left attached to the instance during the rebuild. * Resize (with change of flavor): It is equivalent to a termination followed by re-scheduling and restart. The accelerator resources are detached on termination, and re-attached on when the instance is scheduled again.* Evacuate: This is a forcible rebuild by the administrator. As the semantics of evacuation are left open even without accelerators, Cyborg's behavior is also left undefined. * Set administrator password, trigger crash dump: These are supported and are no-ops for accelerators. The following instance operations are allowed, though they have the potential to cause problems. The operator may use RBAC to limit such operations. * Reboot: The accelerator resources are left intact. However, the DMA buffers and other resources are lost after reboot, so any attempt by the device to access those resources can be problematic. The instance can reset the accelerator(s) after reboot, but that requires trusting the instance. * Booting off a snapshot: The accelerator resources are left intact. But the snapshot may have been taken when the attached accelerators were in a particular state. When booting off a previous snapshot, the current configuration and state of accelerators may not match the snapshot. The instance can reset the accelerator(s) to a clean state after the boot, but that requires trusting the instance.Os-acc Library ============== Overview -------- Nova Compute (n-cpu) on the compute node shall interact with Cyborg and otherwise handle accelerators through a new library named os-acc. This library handles the attach and detach of accelerators to instances, somewhat similar to the way that os-vif handles Neutron ports. The accelerator - instance attachment has two parts: * The connection between the accelerator and a host-visible attach handle, such as a PCI function or a mediated device UUID. We call this the Device Half of the attach. * The connection between the attach handle and the instance. We name this the Instance Half of the attach. There are a few key differences between Neutron ports and Cyborg accelerators, and that translates into differences in the workflow and in the design of os-acc vs. os-vif: * Each Neutron port needs to be provisioned with a unique MAC and IP, but there is no such need today for accelerators. This implies that the port binding step has no analog for accelerators. * To create the Device Half of the attach, the device may need to be configured in some way, such as associating the accelerator to a PCI function in the hardware, or reprogramming the FPGA. Whereas there is no need to do that for NICs in Neutron. * Nova handles PCI for Neutron while Cyborg handles it for accelerators. This means that os-acc must provide the PCI function data, if any, for the Instance Half of the attach. The broad steps for attaching an accelerator to an instance are as below: * Create a Virtual Accelerator Nexus (VAN), analogous to a VIF, which is a handle object for attaching an accelerator to an instance (see `VANs and plugins`_). * Create the Device Half of the attach: * Choose an accelerator in the chosen device RP (resource provider) if there is more than one. * If needed, create a host-visible attach handle, such as a mediated device UUID. * If needed, configure the device hardware to associate the chosen accelerator with a host-visible attach handle (PCI function, mediated device, etc.) * Update the VAN to record the accelerator and attach handle association. * Persist the VAN object and the instance-VAN association. * Create the Instance Half of the attach: * Use the VAN information in a hypervisor-specific way to attach the accelerator to the instance. .. _VANfactors: The process of attaching a device to a VM and detaching it depends on many factors, as apparent from the above: * Accelerator type: GPU, FPGA, etc. * Mechanism: plain PCI, SR-IOV, mediated device, etc. * System architecture: x86, ARM, Power etc. * Hypervisor: libvirt+qemu, libvirt+Xen, etc. * Vendor/device-specific actions. To accommodate this wide variation, os-acc will adopt a plugin-based architecture. That is, os-acc will call into a suitable plugin for each instance request, and the plugin handles most of the attach/detach. It is expected that different device types like GPUs and FPGAs will be handled by different plugins. The APIs exposed by plugins to os-acc are specified later in `Os-acc - Plugin API`_. However, the os-vif plugins deal with a small set of entities to which Neutron ports connect: Linux bridge, OVS, SR-IOV etc. Whereas os-acc plugins are expected to handle a much wider range of variation among devices. So, instead of having the Nova virt driver choose a plugin as with os-vif, os-acc will let the operator specify a set of plugins in a configuration file (``setup.cfg``) and will load them through stevedore (similar to Neutron controller plugins). Out-of-tree plugins can be enabled in this way. Workflow -------- The end-to-end workflow for instance creation and scheduling with accelerators is as follows: 0. Cyborg agent and drivers discover devices and resources in each node. The agent propagates the data to the Cyborg conductor, which persists it in the db, and then populates Placement with the corresponding resource providers and resource classes. Details in [#CyborgNovaSched]_. #. The user submits a instance creation request. An example:: openstack server create --flavor my-acc ... Flavor my-acc includes: resources:CUSTOM_ACCELERATOR_GPU=1 traits:CUSTOM_GPU_VENDOR_X=required #. Nova API receives the request and sends it to the Nova conductor, which in turn forwards it to the Nova scheduler. #. The scheduler invokes Placement to get a list of allocation candidates, i.e., compute node RPs including the UUID of the chosen device RP within each node. #. The scheduler chooses a compute node and a specific device RP. It then invokes Nova Compute (n-cpu) on that compute node via RPC. #. The n-cpu notes that one of the requested resources is of the form CUSTOM_ACCELERATOR_* and so decides to invoke os-acc. The interaction with os-acc can happen concurrently with other tasks for spawning the instance. #. The n-cpu first needs to get the Virtual Accelerator Nexus (VAN), which is a handle object for attaching an accelerator to an instance (see `VANs and plugins`_). So, it calls the ``getVAN()`` API in os-acc (see `Nova Compute - Os-acc API`_). #. The os-acc loads an appropriate plugin for that request, as discussed in `Os-acc - Plugin API`_. #. The os-acc then calls a well-known API in the plugin to create the Device Half of the attach and thus get a VAN object. A reference to the plugin may be stored in the VAN for use in subsequent calls for the same VAN. The plugin *may* call the Cyborg agent on the node to do the job, but *must* call the Cyborg agent to have the VAN object persisted (via the Cyborg conductor). The process of getting a VAN object also serves to bind a specific accelerator instance in the chosen device RP to that VAN. It may also initiate programming in the case of FPGAs. #. The n-cpu then calls the ``plug()`` API in os-acc for the Instance Half of the attach, i.e., to associate the VAN with the instance. For example, in libvirt-based x86 systems, this may return an XML snippet that includes the PCI function encapsulated by the VAN. The instance - VAN association is persisted by Nova. NOTE: The os-vif ``plug()`` API attaches a Neutron port to a bridge, OVS, etc. The os-acc ``plug()`` call does something else. #. Nova virt driver uses the return value of ``plug()`` to complete the attach of the accelerator to the instance. #. The n-cpu spawns the VM with the accelerator attached to it. #. When the instance is deleted, or a single accelerator is detached (through some mechanism TBD), n-cpu calls ``unplug()`` API in os-acc, passing the relevant VAN(s). The os-acc calls the right plugin to get the accelerator instances detached. The plugin *may* call the Cyborg agent to do the detach, but *must* call Cyborg to record the release of the resources. VANs and plugins ---------------- The handle by which an accelerator is attached to a VM is encapsulated as an object named the Virtual Accelerator Nexus (VAN). A VAN could be based on PCI (physical or virtual) functions, mediated devices, etc. A device may have one or more VANs. The number of VANs may be fixed (and statically discoverable, as with PCI functions) or not known initially (and a new one can be created dynamically on request, as with mediated devices). A VAN is somewhat analogous to a VIF, though the analogy is not exact. In particular, it is a versioned object, as shown below, which can be extended/sub-classed as needed to handle different device types:: class VANBase(oslo_versionedobjects.base.VersionedObject): OBJ_PROJECT_NAMESPACE = "os-acc" VERSION = "1.0" fields = { id: UUIDField() # VAN ID hypervisor: AccHypervisorEnumField() # 'LibvirtQemu', LibvirtXen', etc. plugin: StringField() # name of plugin class to load } It can be extended, for example, as below to handle different mechanisms (VANfactors_):: class VANTypePCI(VANBase): fields = { bus: IntegerField() device: IntegerField() function: IntegerField() } class VANTypeMediatedDevice(VANBase): fields = { uuid: UUIDField() . . . } Different device types, device families and hypervisors are handled through plugins, rather than by subclassing VANBase, to avoid proliferation of classes. A plugin is represented by a base class which can be extended in many ways in specific implementations:: class VANPluginBase(Object): # similar to VIFPlug VERSION = "1.0" def plug(self, van, instance_info): raise NotImplementedError def unplug(self, van, instance_info): raise NotImplementedError def describe(self): raise NotImplementedError @classmethod def load(cls, plugin_name) raise NotImplementedError # ... other APIs ... (See `Os-acc - Plugin API`_ for the full definition.) The main factors involved in attaching an accelerator (see VANfactors_) are the device type, hypervisor type, mechanism, and system architecture. It is proposed to have a modular design, where functionality relating to a specific factor is provided by classes specific to that factor. For example, there would be classes for specific device types:: class VANImplTypeGPU(Object): # methods here are only examples def create_vgpu(...): raise NotImplementedError def change_vgpu_type(...): raise NotImplementedError # etc. class VANImplTypeFPGA(Object): def program_region(region_rp_uuid, bitstream_glance_uuid, ...): raise NotImplementedError # etc. Similarly, we can have additional sets of classes for other factors: * Mechanisms: ``VANImplMechPCI, VANImplMechSRIOV, VanImplMechMdev, ...`` * Hypervisor: ``VANImplHypervisorLibvirtQemu,`` ``VANImplHypervisorLibvirtXen, ...`` A plugin implementation may use these classes either by composition or by inheritance from mix-ins:: # uses inheritance from mix-in classes class VANPluginExample1(VANImplTypeGPU, VANImplMechSRIOV, VANImplHypervisorLibvirtQemu, VANPluginBase): . . . # uses composition class VANPluginExample2(VANPluginBase): def __init__(self, type, mech, hypervisor): self._type = type self._mech = mech self._hypervisor = hypervisor # plug, unplug, etc. Nova Compute - Os-acc API ------------------------- Nova Compute calls the os-acc APIs if it sees that the requested flavor refers to CUSTOM_ACCELERATOR_* resource classes. The APIs are called asynchronously, as suggested below:: with ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=N) as executor: # ... do other stuff ...The only exception is the ``initialize()`` call, which is called synchronously and unconditionally when Nova Compute starts up. The os-acc class is defined as below:: class os_acc(Object): VERSION = "1.0" def initialize(self): # called by n-cpu at start return None def getVAN(self, device_rp, extra_specs, instance_info): ... return van def plug(self, van, instance_info): pass def unplug(self, van, instance_info): pass The semantics of these APIs are specified below. .. _initialize: * Called once at startup of Nova compute. Loads os-acc plugins using stevedore's ``ExtensionManager``. Waits for Cyborg Agent to be ready to accept requests, i.e., all devices enumerated and traits published. * Returns None on success. Throws ``CyborgAgentUnavailable`` exception if Cyborg Agent cannot be contacted. * getVAN(self, device_rp, extra_specs, instance_info) * device_rp: The nested RP selected by the scheduler is needed for Cyborg to correlate it to a deployable. Read-only. * extra_specs: the extra_specs field in the flavor, including fields interpreted by Cyborg but not Nova. Read-only. * instance_info: Nova's per-instance dictionary. Read-only. * The VM image UUID may be used to query Glance for metadata about accelerator requirements that may be stored with the VM image (i.e., traits in images instead of flavors). * The project ID may be used for policy-based decisions in the future if more than one bitstream matches the need. * NOTE: In the future, if we need to provision/configure any resource on a per-accelerator basis, similar to MAC/IP provisioning for Neutron ports, that can be accommodated in this API. * Summary: Allocates a specific accelerator instance from the device_rp, possibly after configuring the device as needed, binds it to a VAN object and persists the VAN. * Details: os-acc will call the getVAN() API of a suitable plugin. The plugin may call into Cyborg Agent. This call chain may fetch bitstreams from Glance and initiate programming. It may involve invoking a vendor-specific driver to prepare/configure the device hardware or create mediated devices. Cyborg conductor may get invoked to get a PCI VF or other resources discovered earlier. Cyborg conductor will get called in this call chain to persist the allocated VAN. .. _FPGAProg: FPGA programming is initiated in this call chain if extra_specs contain one of these pairs (see [#CyborgNovaSched]_): * ``traits:CUSTOM_FPGA_<vendor>_REGION_<uuid>`` and ``bitstream:<uuid>`` * ``traits:CUSTOM_FPGA_<vendor>_FUNCTION_<uuid>`` and (either ``function:<uuid>`` or ``function-name:<name>``) * Returns a VAN if successful, or None on failure. * plug(self, van, instance_info) * van: VAN object obtained via getVAN(). * instance_info: Read-only. * This call handles the Instance Half of the attach. (In os-vif plugins, this call attaches a Neutron port to a bridge, OVS or SR-IOV function. The functionality here is different.) * Returns a hypervisor-specific value on success. For example, for libvirt, it may return an XML snippet with PCI passthrough data. Throws exceptions on failure. * NOTE: Nova virt drivers need to use the return value of ``plug()`` to complete the attach of the accelerator to the instance. * unplug(self, van, instance_info) * van: VAN object. * instance_info: Read-only. * As part of this call, Cyborg Agent will clean up internal resources, call the appropriate Cyborg driver to clean up the device resources and update its data structures persistently. * Returns None on success, throws exceptions on failure. Os-acc - Plugin API ------------------- The os-acc loads all plugins during ``os_acc.initialize()`` call using stevedore's ``ExtensionManager`` class. All plugins shall reside in the ``os-acc`` namespace. The operator must configure the needed plugins in a configuration file (``setup.cfg``). Unlike os-vif, where Nova virt chooses a plugin, the os-acc needs a more flexible mechanism to handle plugins. That is proposed below. For an attach request, the os-acc will choose a plugin by querying every loaded plugin in alphabetical order of plugin name to check if it can handle that request. The first plugin to 'claim' the request gets to handle it. If there are two or more plugins that can potentially handle the request, the operator can prioritize one by naming it suitably in the ``setup.cfg`` file (similar to rc scripts in Linux). Since the number of os-acc plugins in a given host is expected to be small (even if the number in the community is large), this may be efficient enough. If further efficiencies are needed in the future, we could: * Cache the plugin data in some form. * Have each plugin provide metadata about its parameters such as supported device types, and organize separate plugin chains. The resulting chains will be shorter. The full definition of the VAN plugin base class is as follows:: class VANPluginBase(Object): VERSION = "1.0" def plug(self, van, instance_info): raise NotImplementedError def unplug(self, van, instance_info): raise NotImplementedError def describe(self): raise NotImplementedError @classmethod def load(cls, plugin_name) raise NotImplementedError def getVAN(self, device_rp, extra_specs, instance_data): # same signature as corresponding os-acc API raise NotImplementedError @classmethod def can_handle(cls, rc, device_rp, extra_specs, instance_info): # rc: resource class of the accelerator e.g. CUSTOM_ACCELERATOR_GPU # device_rp implicitly indicates the device family # returns True/False return False The ``plug(), unplug(), describe(), load()`` and ``getVAN()`` calls work the same way as for os-acc. The ``can_handle`` method returns a boolean indicating whether this class can handle the request. As part of that, it may query Cyborg with the device RP uuid and obtain the device information. Since that is likely to be needed in ``getVAN()``, this method may cache the information as a class variable. To handle the device/vendor-specific aspects, which are already handled by Cyborg drivers, there are two options: * Have the plugin call into Cyborg agent, which in turn calls into the Cyborg drivers. Since the plugin has to call Cyborg anyway to have the VAN persisted, this is the most reasonable option. * Have Cyborg drivers provide a plugin interface as well, so that they can be loaded by both the plugin and Cyborg agent. Glance Interaction ================== Cyborg shall store FPGA bitstreams in Glance. The metadata for the bitstreams shall be stored as Glance properties. Though Glance also offers tags, the properties allow protections, i.e., access permissions for specific users/roles, which can be useful in protecting bitstream access integrity. Cyborg shall access Glance, through the glance client, to fetch bitstreams for programming, either as part of an instance creation request (see FPGAProg_) or in response to Cyborg REST API invocations for programming an FPGA region or shell logic. No changes are required in Glance to support Cyborg. In the future, when Glance images can have traits, the accelerator requirements for a VM image may be expressed as image traits instead of traits in the flavor.The os-acc could support one plugin per accelerator type (GPU, FPGA, etc.), and let them handle further sub-plugins for different devices. That is probably unnecessary.Cyborg needs to persist the VANs. Nova needs to persist the VAN - instance association.Cyborg Agent needs to provide an RPC API (not REST API) for os_acc to check its readiness (initialize_).Nova may choose to add additional notifications relating to os-acc invocation.The operator must ensure the correct set of os-acc plugins for each host are set up in the os-acc ``setup.cfg`` file.Nova and Cyborg shall jointly maintain the os-acc framework. Though plugins are device-dependent, some parts like the ``plug()`` API are hypervisor-specific rather than device-specific, and hence can be maintained together.* `Nested Resource Provider support <http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/pike/approved/nested-resource-providers.html>`_ in Nova, to represent devices as nested RPs. to allow operators to define flavors that request different types of accelerators.We need a test framework for os-acc. For each plugin supported in this release, we need to integrate the corresponding device type(s) in the CI infrastructure... [#ComputeNodeSpec] `Cyborg Compute Node specification <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/566798/>`_ .. [#os-vif] `Os-vif Code and Documentation <https://github.com/openstack/os-vif>`_ new design, API or any database schema updated. Useful to let reader understand what's happened along the time.
deleted_lines: Cyborg is a service for managing accelerators, such as FPGAs, GPUs, etc. For scheduling an instance that needs accelerators, Cyborg needs to work with Nova at three levels: as resources in Placement. When a device is discovered, Cyborg updates resource inventories in Placement. * Instance placement/scheduling: Cyborg may provide a weigher that prioritizes hosts based on available accelerator resources. * Attaching accelerators to instances. In the compute node, Cyborg shall define a workflow based on interacting with Nova through a new os-acc library (like os-vif and os-brick).addresses the attachment of accelerators to instances, via os-acc. For FPGAs, Cyborg also needs to interact with Glance for fetching bitstreams. Some aspects of that are covered in [#BitstreamSpec]_. This spec will address the interaction of Cyborg and Glance in the compute node.Smart NICs based on FPGAs fall into two categories: those which expose the FPGA explicitly to the host, and those that do not. Cyborg's current scope includes the former. This spec includes such devices, though the Cyborg-Neutron interaction is out of scope. The scope of this spec is Rocky release. functions in a region:: PCI A PCI B | | +-------|--------|-------------------+ | | | | | +----|--------|---+ +--------+ | | | +--|--+ +---|-+ | | | | | | | Fn A| | Fn B| | | | | | | +-----+ +-----+ | | | | | +-----------------+ +--------+ | | Region 1 Region 2 | | | +------------------------------------+ Problem description =================== Once Nova has picked a compute node for placement of an instance that needs accelerators, the following steps needs to happen: * Nova compute on that node has to invoke Cyborg Agent for handling the needed accelerators. This needs to happen through a library, named os-acc, patterned after os-vif (Neutron) and os-brick (Cinder). * Cyborg Agent may call Glance to fetch a bitstream, either by id or based on tags. * Cyborg Agent may need to call into a Cyborg driver to program said bitstream. * Cyborg Agent needs to call into a Cyborg driver to prepare a device and/or obtain an attach handle (e.g. PCI BDF) that can be attached to the instance. * Cyborg Agent returns enough information to Nova compute via os-acc for the instance to be launched. The behavior of each of these steps needs to be specified. In addition, the OpenStack Compute API [#ServerConcepts]_ specifies the operations that can be done on an instance. The behavior with respect to accelerators must be defined for each of these operations. That in turn is related to when Nova compute calls os-acc. Use Cases --------- Please see [#CyborgNovaSched]_. We intend to support FPGAaaS with request time programming, and AFaaS (both pre-programmed and orchestrator-programmed scenarios). Cyborg will discover accelerator resources whenever the Cyborg agent starts up. PCI hot plug can be supported past Rocky release. Cyborg must support all instance operations mentioned in OpenStack Compute API [#ServerConcepts]_ in Rocky, except booting off a snapshot and live migration. Proposed change ===============-----------------------------Cyborg in Rocky. The list of supported operations (with the intended behaviors) are as follows: * When an instance is started, the accelerators requested by that instance’s flavor must be attached to the instance. On termination, those resources are released. * When an instance is paused, suspended or locked, the accelerator resources are left intact, and not detached from the instance. So, when the instance is unpaused, resumed or unlocked, there is nothing to do.* Reboot: The accelerator resources are left intact. It is up the instance software to rediscover attached resources. * Rebuild: Prior to the instance image replacement, all device access must be quiesced, i.e., accesses to devices from that instance must be completed and further accesses must be prohibited. The mechanics of such quiescing are outside the scope of this document. With that precondition, accelerator resources are left attached to the instance during the rebuild. * Resize (with change of flavor): It is equivalent to a termination followed by re-scheduling and restart. The accelerator resources are detached on termination, and re-attached on when the instance is scheduled again.* Evacuate: This is a forcible rebuild by the administrator. As the semantics of evacuation are left open even without accelerators, Cyborg’s behavior is also left undefined. * Set administrator password, trigger crash dump: These are supported and not no-ops for accelerators.* Booting off a snapshot: The snapshot may have been taken when the attached accelerators were in a particular state. When booting off a previous snapshot, the current configuration and state of accelerators may not match the snapshot. So, this is unsupported. os_acc Structure ---------------- Cyborg will develop a new library named os-acc. That library will offer the APIs listed later in this section. Nova Compute calls these APIs if it sees that the requested flavor refers to CUSTOM_ACCELERATOR resource class, except for the initialize() call, which is called unconditionally. Nova Compute calls these APIs asynchronously, as suggested below:: with ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=1) as executor: # do other stuffThe APIs of os-acc are as below: * Called once at start of day. Waits for Cyborg Agent to be ready to accept requests, i.e., all devices enumerated and traits published. * Returns None on success. * Throws ``CyborgAgentUnavailable`` exception if Cyborg Agent cannot be contacted. * plug(instance_info, selected_rp, flavor_extra_specs) * Parameters are all read-only. Here are their descriptions: * instance_info: dictionary containing instance UUID, instance name, project/tenant ID and VM image UUID. The instance name is needed for better logging, the project/tenant ID may be passed to some accelerator policy engine in the future and the VM image UUID may be used to query Glance for metadata about accelerator requirements that may be stored with the VM image. * selected_rp: Information about the selected resource provider is passed as a dictionary. * flavor_extra_specs: the extra_specs field in the flavor, including resource classes, traits and other fields interpreted by Cyborg. * Called by Nova compute when an instance is started, unshelved, or restored and after a resize or cold migration. * Called before an instance is built, i.e., before the specification of the instance is created. For libvirt-based hypervisors, this means the call happens before the instance’s domain XML is created. * As part of this call, Cyborg Agent may fetch bitstreams from Glance and initiate programming. It may fetch the bitstream specified in the request’s flavor extra specs, if any. If the request refers to a function ID/name, Cyborg Agent would query Glance to find bitstreams that provide the flavor and match the chosen device, and would then fetch the needed bitstream. * As part of this call, Cyborg Agent will locate the Deployable corresponding to the chosen RP, locate the attach handles (e.g. PCI BDF) needed, update its internal data structures in a persistent way, and return the needed information back to Nova. * Returns an array, with one entry per requested accelerator, each entry being a dictionary. The dictionary is structured as below for Rocky: | { “pci_id”: <pci bdf> } * unplug(instance_info) * Parameters are all read-only. Here are their descriptions: * instance_info: dictionary containing instance UUID and instance name. The instance name is needed for better logging. * Called when an instance is stopped, shelved, or deleted and before a resize or cold migration. * As part of this call, Cyborg Agent will clean up internal resources, call the appropriate Cyborg driver to clean up the device resources and update its data structures persistently. * Returns the number of accelerators that were released. Errors may cause exceptions to be thrown. Workflows --------- The pseudocode for each os-acc API can be expressed as below:: def initialize(): # checks that all devices are discovered and their traits published # waits if any discovery operation is ongoing return None def plug(instance_info, rp, extra_specs): validate_params(....) glance = glanceclient.Client(...) driver = # select Cyborg driver for chosen rp rp_deployable = # get deployable for RP if extra_specs refers to ``CUSTOM_FPGA_<vendor>_REGION_<uuid>`` and extra_specs refers to ``bitstream:<uuid>``: bitstream = glance.images.data(image_uuid) driver.program(bitstream, rp_deployable, …) if extra_specs refers to ``CUSTOM_FPGA_<vendor>_FUNCTION_<uuid>`` and extra_specs refers to function UUID/name: region_type_uuid = # fetch from selected RP bitstreams = glance.images.list(...) # queries Glance by function UUID/name property and region type # UUID to get matching bitstreams if len(bitstreams) > 1: error(...) # bitstream choice policy is outside Cyborg driver.program(bitstream, rp_deployable, …) pci_bdf = driver.allocate_handle(...) # update Cyborg DB with instance_info and BDF usage return { “pci_id”: pci bdf } def unplug(instance_info): bdf_list = # fetch BDF usage from Cyborg DB for instance # update Cyborg DB to mark those BDFs as free return len(bdf_list)N/ANoneNoneNoneNoneNone* Decide how to associate multiple functions/bitstreams in extra specs with multiple devices in the flavor. * Others: TBD * Nested Resource Provider support in NovaFor each vendor driver supported in this release, we need to integrate the corresponding FPGA type(s) in the CI infrastructure.new design, API or any database schema updated. Useful to let reader understand what's happened along the time.

added_lines: self.fake_job_id = common.get_fake_job_id() def test_add_and_replace_job(self): job_doc = copy.deepcopy(self.fake_job_0) job_id = self.dbapi.add_job(user_id=self.fake_job_0.get('user_id'), doc=job_doc, project_id=self.fake_project_id) self.assertIsNotNone(job_id) patch_doc = copy.deepcopy(self.fake_job_2) result = self.dbapi.replace_job(user_id=self. fake_job_2.get('user_id'), job_id=job_id, doc=patch_doc, project_id=self.fake_project_id) self.assertIsNotNone(result) self.assertEqual(result, job_id) result = self.dbapi.get_job(project_id=self.fake_project_id, user_id=self.fake_job_2.get('user_id'), job_id=job_id) self.assertIsNotNone(result) self.assertEqual(result.get('client_id'), self.fake_job_2.get('client_id')) self.assertEqual(result.get('description'), self.fake_job_2.get('description')) self.assertEqual(result.get('job_schedule'). get('schedule_interval'), self.fake_job_2.get('job_schedule'). get('schedule_interval')) self.assertEqual(result.get('job_actions'), self.fake_job_2.get('job_actions')) patch_doc1 = copy.deepcopy(self.fake_job_0) result = self.dbapi.replace_job(user_id=self. fake_job_2.get('user_id'), job_id=self.fake_job_id, doc=patch_doc1, project_id=self.fake_project_id) self.assertIsNotNone(result) self.assertEqual(result, self.fake_job_id)

commit_message:
Add framework for panko-status upgrade check

This commit adds the functionality of panko-status CLI for performing
upgrade checks as part of the Stein cycle upgrade-checkers goal.
It only includes a sample check which must be replaced by real checks in
future.

Change-Id: Ice0df931b8bd111b0a99ab70633c1b2aabb3c051
Story: 2003657
Task: 27734
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/panko refs/changes/04/614404/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2018 NEC, Corp. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import sys from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_upgradecheck import upgradecheck from panko.i18n import _ CONF = cfg.CONF class Checks(upgradecheck.UpgradeCommands): """Contains upgrade checks Various upgrade checks should be added as separate methods in this class and added to _upgrade_checks tuple. """ def _sample_check(self): """This is sample check added to test the upgrade check framework It needs to be removed after adding any real upgrade check """ return upgradecheck.Result(upgradecheck.Code.SUCCESS, 'Sample detail') _upgrade_checks = ( # Sample check added for now. # Whereas in future real checks must be added here in tuple (_('Sample Check'), _sample_check), ) def main(): return upgradecheck.main( CONF, project='panko', upgrade_command=Checks()) if __name__ == '__main__': sys.exit(main())

commit_message:
doc: Add minimal documentation for MKS consoles

I did know this was a thing but only barely. As with RDP, the
documentation is very minimal but it should contain enough pointers for
anyone playing with this stuff.

Change-Id: I0b62d42eae7c325566ee065dcdc0f73b7223d471
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/93/606993/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: MKS --- MKS is the protocol used for accessing the console of a virtual machine running on VMware vSphere. It is very similar to VNC. Due to the architecture of the VMware vSphere hypervisor, it is not necessary to run a console proxy service. Similarly, it is not necessary to run the :program:`nova-consoleauth` service as token management is handled by the hypervisor. As a result, only the :program:`nova-compute` service must be configured. All options are defined in the :oslo:config:group:`mks` group. The :program:`nova-compute` service requires the following options to configure MKS console support. These can only be configured via a configuration file. - :oslo:config:option:`mks.enabled` - :oslo:config:option:`mks.mksproxy_base_url` For example, to configure this via a ``nova.conf`` file: .. code-block:: console [mks] enabled = True mksproxy_base_url = https://127.0.0.1:6090/

doc: Add minimal documentation for RDP consoles

I didn't even know this was a thing. Call it out...and promptly link to
the Cloudbase documentation, which I don't want to reproduce here for
reasons of expediency.

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/92/606992/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: VNC, SPICE, Serial, RDP or MKS. If configured, these can be accessed by users through the OpenStack dashboard or the command line. This document outlines how these different technologies can be configured.RDP --- RDP is a graphical console primarily used with Hyper-V. Nova does not provide a console proxy service for RDP - instead, an external proxy service, such as the :program:`wsgate` application provided by `FreeRDP-WebConnect`__, should be used. A typical deployment has the following components: - A :program:`nova-consoleauth` process. Typically runs on the controller host. - One or more :program:`wsgate` services (or other RDP console proxy service). For simple deployments, this service typically runs on the same machine as :program:`nova-api` because it operates as a proxy between the public network and the private compute host network. __ https://github.com/FreeRDP/FreeRDP-WebConnect Configuration ~~~~~~~~~~~~~ To enable the RDP console service, you must configure both a console proxy service like :program:`wsgate` and the :program:`nova-compute` service. All options for the latter service are defined in the :oslo.config:group:`rdp` group. Information on configuring an RDP console proxy service, such as :program:`wsgate`, is not provided here. However, more information can be found at `cloudbase.it`__. The :program:`nova-compute` service requires the following options to configure RDP console support. These can only be configured via a configuration file. - :oslo.config:option:`rdp.enabled` - :oslo.config:option:`rdp.html5_proxy_base_url` For example, to configure this via a ``nova.conf`` file: .. code-block:: console [serial_console] enabled = True html5_proxy_base_url = https://IP_ADDRESS:6083/ Replace ``IP_ADDRESS`` with the IP address from which the proxy is accessible by the outside world. For example, this may be the management interface IP address of the controller or the VIP. __ https://cloudbase.it/freerdp-html5-proxy-windows/
deleted_lines: VNC, SPICE HTML5 or Serial console. If configured, these can be accessed by users through the OpenStack dashboard or the command line. This document outlines how these different technologies can be configured.

commit_message:
doc: Rewrite the console doc

The link between the various consoles was never well understood (by me,
at least). Clarify this by restructuring the document to highlight the
few differences between these services.

Change-Id: I08991796aaced2abc824f608108c0c786181eb65
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/48/606148/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: OpenStack provides a number of different methods to interact with your guests: VNC, SPICE HTML5 or Serial console. If configured, these can be accessed by users through the OpenStack dashboard or the command line. This document outlines how these different technologies can be configured. Overview -------- It is considered best practice to deploy only one of VNC, SPICE HTML5 or Serial Console. Regardless of what option is chosen, a proxy service is required. These services are responsible for the following: - Provide a bridge between the public network where the clients live and the private network where VNC servers live. - Mediate token authentication. - Transparently handle hypervisor-specific connection details to provide a uniform client experience. Consider a VNC console connection, for example: through the :oslo.config:option:`vnc.server_proxyclient_address` option. InThis particular example is illustrated below. .. _about-nova-consoleauth: About ``nova-consoleauth`` -------------------------- The :doc:`/cli/nova-consoleauth` service provides a shared service to manage token authentication that the client proxies outlined below can leverage. This service must be running for either proxy to work. Many proxies of either type can be run against a single :program:`nova-consoleauth` service in a cluster configuration. .. important:: Do not confuse the :program:`nova-consoleauth` shared service with :doc:`/cli/nova-console` service, which is a XenAPI-specific service that most recent VNC proxy architectures do not use. .. deprecated:: 18.0.0 ``nova-consoleauth`` is deprecated since 18.0.0 (Rocky) and will be removed in an upcoming release. noVNC-based VNC console proxy ----------------------------- The :doc:`/cli/nova-novncproxy` service uses noVNC to provide VNC support through a web browser. A typical deployment has the following components: - A :program:`nova-consoleauth` process. Typically runs on the controller host. - One or more :program:`nova-novncproxy` services. Supports browser-based noVNC clients. For simple deployments, this service typically runs on the same machine as :program:`nova-api` because it operates as a proxy between the public network and the private compute host network. .. note:: The web proxy console URLs do not support the websocket protocol scheme (ws://) on python versions less than 2.7.4. .. note:: It has `been reported`__ that versions of noVNC older than 0.6 do not work with the :program:`nova-novncproxy` service. If using non-US key mappings, then you need at least noVNC 1.0.0 for `a fix`__. __ https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1752896 __ https://github.com/novnc/noVNC/commit/99feba6ba8fee5b3a2b2dc99dc25e9179c560d31 .. _vnc-security: Configuration ~~~~~~~~~~~~~ To enable the noVNC VNC console service, you must configure both the :program:`nova-novncproxy` service and the :program:`nova-compute` service. All options are defined in the :oslo.config:group:`vnc` group. The :program:`nova-novncproxy` service takes a number options. The can be provided via a configuration file or via the command line. - :oslo.config:option:`vnc.novncproxy_host` - :oslo.config:option:`vnc.novncproxy_port` - :oslo.config:option:`vnc.auth_schemes` - :oslo.config:option:`vnc.vencrypt_client_key` - :oslo.config:option:`vnc.vencrypt_client_cert` - :oslo.config:option:`vnc.vencrypt_ca_certs` For example, to configure this via a ``nova-novncproxy.conf`` file: .. code-block:: console [vnc] novncproxy_host = 0.0.0.0 novncproxy_port = 6082 This doesn't show configuration with security. For information on how to configure this, refer to :ref:`vnc-security` above. The :program:`nova-compute` service takes a number of options. These can only be provided via a configuration file. - :oslo.config:option:`vnc.enabled` - :oslo.config:option:`vnc.novncproxy_base_url` - :oslo.config:option:`vnc.server_listen` - :oslo.config:option:`vnc.server_proxyclient_address` - :oslo.config:option:`vnc.keymap` For example, to configure this via a ``nova.conf`` file: .. code-block:: console [vnc] enabled = True novncproxy_base_url = http://IP_ADDRESS:6082/vnc_auto.html server_listen = 127.0.0.1 server_proxyclient_address = 127.0.0.1 keymap = en-us Replace ``IP_ADDRESS`` with the management interface IP address of the controller or the VIP. XVP-based VNC console proxy --------------------------- The :doc:`/cli/nova-xvpvncproxy` service use XVP to provide VNC support via a simple Java client. It is only supported by the Xen driver.- A :program:`nova-consoleauth` process. Typically runs on the controller host. - One or more :program:`nova-xvpvncproxy` services. Supports the special Java client discussed above. For simple deployments, this service typically runs on the same machine as :program:`nova-api` because it acts as a proxy between the public network and the private compute host network. Configuration ~~~~~~~~~~~~~ To enable the XVP VNC console service, you must configure both the :program:`nova-xvpvncproxy` service and the :program:`nova-compute` service. All options are defined in the :oslo.config:group:`vnc` group. The :program:`nova-xvpvncproxy` service takes a number options. The can be provided via a configuration file or via the command line. - :oslo.config:option:`vnc.xvpvncproxy_host` - :oslo.config:option:`vnc.xvpvncproxy_port` For example, to configure this via a ``nova-xvpvncproxy.conf`` file: [vnc] xvpvncproxy_host = 0.0.0.0 xvpvncproxy_port = 6081 The :program:`nova-compute` service takes a number of options. These can only be provided via a configuration file. - :oslo.config:option:`vnc.enabled` - :oslo.config:option:`vnc.xvpvncproxy_base_url` - :oslo.config:option:`vnc.server_listen` - :oslo.config:option:`vnc.server_proxyclient_address` - :oslo.config:option:`vnc.keymap` For example, to configure this via a ``nova.conf`` file: [vnc] enabled = True xvpvncproxy_base_url = http://IP_ADDRESS:6081/console server_listen = 127.0.0.1 server_proxyclient_address = 127.0.0.1 keymap = en-us Replace ``IP_ADDRESS`` with the management interface IP address of the controller or the VIP. SPICE console ------------- The :doc:`/cli/nova-spicehtml5proxy` service provides SPICE support via the web browser. The VNC protocol is fairly limited, lacking support for multiple monitors, bi-directional audio, reliable cut-and-paste, video streaming and more. SPICE is a new protocol that aims to address the limitations in VNC and provide good remote desktop support. SPICE support in OpenStack Compute shares a similar architecture to the VNC implementation. The OpenStack dashboard uses a SPICE-HTML5 widget in its console tab that communicates to the :program:`nova-spicehtml5proxy` service by using SPICE-over-websockets. The :program:`nova-spicehtml5proxy` service communicates directly with the hypervisor process by using SPICE. Configuration ~~~~~~~~~~~~~ .. important:: VNC must be explicitly disabled to get access to the SPICE console. Set the :oslo.config:option:`vnc.enabled` option to ``False`` to disable the VNC console. To enable the SPICE console service, you must configure both the :program:`nova-spicehtml5proxy` service and the :program:`nova-compute` service. All options are defined in the :oslo.config:group:`spice` group. The :program:`nova-spicehtml5proxy` service takes two options. These can be provided via a configuration file or via the command line. - :oslo.config:option:`spice.html5proxy_host` - :oslo.config:option:`spice.html5proxy_port` For example, to configure this via a ``nova-serialconsole.conf`` file: .. code-block:: console [spice] html5proxy_host = 0.0.0.0 html5proxy_port = 6082 The :program:`nova-compute` service takes many more options. These can only be provided via a configuration file. - :oslo.config:option:`spice.enabled` - :oslo.config:option:`spice.agent_enabled` - :oslo.config:option:`spice.html5proxy_base_url` - :oslo.config:option:`spice.server_listen` - :oslo.config:option:`spice.server_proxyclient_address` - :oslo.config:option:`spice.keymap` For example, to configure this via a ``nova.conf`` file: .. code-block:: console [spice] agent_enabled = False enabled = True html5proxy_base_url = http://IP_ADDRESS:6082/spice_auto.html server_listen = 127.0.0.1 server_proxyclient_address = 127.0.0.1 keymap = en-us Replace ``IP_ADDRESS`` with the management interface IP address of the controller or the VIP. Serial Console -------------- The :doc:`/cli/nova-serialproxy` service is an alternative to graphical consoles like VNC or SPICE. The example below uses these nodes: * controller node with IP ``192.168.50.100`` * compute node 1 with IP ``192.168.50.104`` * compute node 2 with IP ``192.168.50.105`` Here's the general flow of actions: .. figure:: figures/serial-console-flow.svg :width: 100% :alt: The serial console flow 1. The user requests a serial console connection string for an instance from the REST API. 2. The ``nova-api`` service asks the ``nova-compute`` service, which manages that instance, to fulfill that request. 3. That connection string gets used by the user to connect to the ``nova-serialproxy`` service. 4. The ``nova-serialproxy`` service then proxies the console interaction to the port of the compute node where the instance is running. That port gets forwarded by the hypervisor into the KVM guest. For more information, refer to the original spec [1]_. Configuration ~~~~~~~~~~~~~ To enable the serial console service, you must configure both the :program:`nova-serialconsole` service and the :program:`nova-compute` service. All options are defined in the :oslo.config:group:`serial_console` group. The :program:`nova-serialconsole` service takes two options. The can be provided via a configuration file or via the command line. - :oslo.config:option:`serial_console.serialproxy_host` - :oslo.config:option:`serial_console.serialproxy_port` For example, to configure this via a ``nova-serialconsole.conf`` file: .. code-block:: console [serial_console] serialproxy_host = 0.0.0.0 serialproxy_port = 6083 The :program:`nova-compute` service takes many more options. These can only be provided via a configuration file. - :oslo.config:option:`serial_console.enabled` - :oslo.config:option:`serial_console.base_url` - :oslo.config:option:`serial_console.proxyclient_address` - :oslo.config:option:`serial_console.port_range` For example, to configure this via a ``nova.conf`` file: .. code-block:: console [serial_console] enabled = True base_url = ws://IP_ADDRESS:6083/ proxyclient_address = 127.0.0.1 port_range = 10000:20000 Replace ``IP_ADDRESS`` with the management interface IP address of the controller or the VIP. There are some things to keep in mind when configuring these options: * :oslo.config:option:`serial_console.serialproxy_host` is the address the :program:`nova-serialproxy` service listens to for incoming connections. * :oslo.config:option:`serial_console.serialproxy_port` must be the same value as the port in the URI of :oslo.config:option:`serial_console.base_url`. * The URL defined in :oslo.config:option:`serial_console.base_url` will form part of the response the user will get when asking for a serial console connection string. This means it needs to be an URL the user can connect to. * :oslo.config:option:`serial_console.proxyclient_address` will be used by the :program:`nova-serialproxy` service to determine where to connect to for proxying the console interaction. Frequently Asked Questions --------------------------
deleted_lines: To provide a remote console or remote desktop access to guest virtual machines, use VNC, SPICE HTML5 or Serial through either the OpenStack dashboard or the command line. Best practice is to select only one of them to run. .. _about-nova-consoleauth: About nova-consoleauth ---------------------- The client proxies leverage a shared service to manage token authentication called ``nova-consoleauth``. This service must be running for either proxy to work. Many proxies of either type can be run against a single ``nova-consoleauth`` service in a cluster configuration. Do not confuse the ``nova-consoleauth`` shared service with ``nova-console``, which is a XenAPI-specific service that most recent VNC proxy architectures do not use. .. deprecated:: 18.0.0 ``nova-consoleauth`` is deprecated since 18.0.0 (Rocky) and will be removed in an upcoming release. SPICE console ------------- OpenStack Compute supports VNC consoles to guests. The VNC protocol is fairly limited, lacking support for multiple monitors, bi-directional audio, reliable cut-and-paste, video streaming and more. SPICE is a new protocol that aims to address the limitations in VNC and provide good remote desktop support. SPICE support in OpenStack Compute shares a similar architecture to the VNC implementation. The OpenStack dashboard uses a SPICE-HTML5 widget in its console tab that communicates to the ``nova-spicehtml5proxy`` service by using SPICE-over-websockets. The ``nova-spicehtml5proxy`` service communicates directly with the hypervisor process by using SPICE. VNC must be explicitly disabled to get access to the SPICE console. Set the ``vnc_enabled`` option to ``False`` in the ``[DEFAULT]`` section to disable the VNC console. Use the following options to configure SPICE as the console for OpenStack Compute: .. code-block:: console [spice] agent_enabled = False enabled = True html5proxy_base_url = http://IP_ADDRESS:6082/spice_auto.html html5proxy_host = 0.0.0.0 html5proxy_port = 6082 keymap = en-us server_listen = 127.0.0.1 server_proxyclient_address = 127.0.0.1 Replace ``IP_ADDRESS`` with the management interface IP address of the controller or the VIP. VNC console proxy ----------------- The VNC proxy is an OpenStack component that enables compute service users to access their instances through VNC clients. .. note:: The web proxy console URLs do not support the websocket protocol scheme (ws://) on python versions less than 2.7.4. The VNC console connection works as follows: through the ``nova.conf`` file option, ``server_proxyclient_address``. InThe proxy also tunnels the VNC protocol over WebSockets so that the ``noVNC`` client can talk to VNC servers. In general, the VNC proxy: - Bridges between the public network where the clients live and the private network where VNC servers live. - Mediates token authentication. - Transparently deals with hypervisor-specific connection details to provide a uniform client experience.VNC configuration options ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ To customize the VNC console, use the following configuration options in your ``nova.conf`` file: To support :ref:`live migration <section_configuring-compute-migrations>`, you cannot specify a specific IP address for ``server_listen``, because that IP address does not exist on the destination host. .. list-table:: **Description of VNC configuration options** :header-rows: 1 :widths: 25 25 * - Configuration option = Default value - Description * - **[DEFAULT]** - * - ``daemon = False`` - (BoolOpt) Become a daemon (background process) * - ``key = None`` - (StrOpt) SSL key file (if separate from cert) * - ``novncproxy_host = 0.0.0.0`` - (StrOpt) Host on which to listen for incoming requests * - ``novncproxy_port = 6080`` - (IntOpt) Port on which to listen for incoming requests * - ``record = False`` - (BoolOpt) Record sessions to FILE.[session_number] * - ``source_is_ipv6 = False`` - (BoolOpt) Source is ipv6 * - ``ssl_only = False`` - (BoolOpt) Disallow non-encrypted connections * - ``web = /usr/share/spice-html5`` - (StrOpt) Run webserver on same port. Serve files from DIR. * - **[vmware]** - * - ``vnc_port = 5900`` - (IntOpt) VNC starting port * - ``vnc_port_total = 10000`` - vnc_port_total = 10000 * - **[vnc]** - * - enabled = True - (BoolOpt) Enable VNC related features * - novncproxy_base_url = http://127.0.0.1:6080/vnc_auto.html - (StrOpt) Location of VNC console proxy, in the form "http://127.0.0.1:6080/vnc_auto.html" * - server_listen = 127.0.0.1 - (StrOpt) IP address on which instance vncservers should listen * - server_proxyclient_address = 127.0.0.1 - (StrOpt) The address to which proxy clients (like nova-xvpvncproxy) should connect * - xvpvncproxy_base_url = http://127.0.0.1:6081/console - (StrOpt) Location of nova xvp VNC console proxy, in the form "http://127.0.0.1:6081/console" .. note:: - The ``server_proxyclient_address`` defaults to ``127.0.0.1``, which is the address of the compute host that Compute instructs proxies to use when connecting to instance servers. - For all-in-one XenServer domU deployments, set this to ``169.254.0.1.`` - For multi-host XenServer domU deployments, set to a ``dom0 management IP`` on the same network as the proxies. - For multi-host libvirt deployments, set to a host management IP on the same network as the proxies. Typical deployment ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~- A ``nova-consoleauth`` process. Typically runs on the controller host. - One or more ``nova-novncproxy`` services. Supports browser-based noVNC clients. For simple deployments, this service typically runs on the same machine as ``nova-api`` because it operates as a proxy between the public network and the private compute host network. - One or more ``nova-xvpvncproxy`` services. Supports the special Java client discussed here. For simple deployments, this service typically runs on the same machine as ``nova-api`` because it acts as a proxy between the public network and the private compute host network. - One or more compute hosts. These compute hosts must have correctly configured options, as follows. nova-novncproxy (noVNC) ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ You must install the noVNC package, which contains the ``nova-novncproxy`` service. As root, run the following command: # apt-get install nova-novncproxy .. note:: It has `been reported`_ that versions of noVNC older than 0.6 do not work with the ``nova-novncproxy`` service. If using non-US key mappings, then you need at least noVNC 1.0.0 for `a fix <https://github.com/novnc/noVNC/commit/99feba6ba8fee5b3a2b2dc99dc25e9179c560d31>`_. .. _been reported: https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1752896 The service starts automatically on installation. To restart the service, run: # service nova-novncproxy restart The configuration option parameter should point to your ``nova.conf`` file, which includes the message queue server address and credentials. By default, ``nova-novncproxy`` binds on ``0.0.0.0:6080``. To connect the service to your Compute deployment, add the following configuration options to your ``nova.conf`` file: - ``server_listen=0.0.0.0`` Specifies the address on which the VNC service should bind. Make sure it is assigned one of the compute node interfaces. This address is the one used by your domain file. .. code-block:: console <graphics type="vnc" autoport="yes" keymap="en-us" listen="0.0.0.0"/> .. note:: To use live migration, use the 0.0.0.0 address. - ``server_proxyclient_address=127.0.0.1`` The address of the compute host that Compute instructs proxies to use when connecting to instance ``vncservers``. Frequently asked questions about VNC access to virtual machines ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Serial Console -------------- The *serial console* feature [1]_ in nova is an alternative for graphical consoles like *VNC*, *SPICE*, *RDP*. The example below uses these nodes: * controller node with IP ``192.168.50.100`` * compute node 1 with IP ``192.168.50.104`` * compute node 2 with IP ``192.168.50.105`` Here's the general flow of actions: .. figure:: figures/serial-console-flow.svg :width: 100% :alt: The serial console flow 1. The user requests a serial console connection string for an instance from the REST API. 2. The `nova-api` service asks the `nova-compute` service, which manages that instance, to fulfill that request. 3. That connection string gets used by the user to connect to the `nova-serialproxy` service. 4. The `nova-serialproxy` service then proxies the console interaction to the port of the compute node where the instance is running. That port gets forwarded by the hypervisor into the KVM guest. The config options for those nodes, which are in the section ``[serial_console]`` of your ``nova.conf``, are not intuitive at first. Keep these things in mind: * The ``serialproxy_host`` is the address the `nova-serialproxy` service listens to for incoming connections (see step 3). * The ``serialproxy_port`` value must be the very same as in the URI of ``base_url``. * The ``base_url`` on the compute node will be part of the response the user will get when asking for a serial console connection string (see step 1 from above). This means it needs to be an URL the user can connect to. * The ``proxyclient_address`` on the compute node will be used by the `nova-serialproxy` service to determine where to connect to for proxying the console interaction.

commit_message:
Deprecate nova-network code

Nova will be removing nova-network soon, this deprecates all
the classes and parameters that are related to nova-network
and will be removed when nova removes it's support.

Please see references in nova.conf [1] and the nova release notes. [2]

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/rocky/configuration/sample-config.html
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/nova/rocky.html

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/614577/
Change-Id: If87ad30e1be62cb767d98045d075340c9513bc90

commit_message:
Deprecate all paste code

Keystone no longer uses it's paste ini file or
uses the paste deploy parts so we deprecate all
that now. [1]

Unfortunately this should probably have been done
in Rocky but got missed, in Stein keystone will
effectively remove the paste ini file. [1]

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/keystone/rocky.html

Change-Id: Ifefea626f754d247b376745fbb2791e725ebafbc

commit_message:
Fix: TestMasakariAPI tests skipped due to missing __init__.py

__init__.py was missing in `masakari.tests.unit.cmd` package, hence
all tests under that package were skipped.

This patch fixes all failing unit tests after adding __init__.py.

Change-Id: I1a0133ff969260397158b0f3ebd7ca87439fd827
Closes-Bug: #1799634

commit_message:
Set hierdata for swift server workers conditionally

If not set, it would use the default os_workers fact instead of 'auto'
and limit the number of worker processes.

Change-Id: I69f51bb38f1307cf4b750e5ffb394eb215df1d9e
(cherry picked from commit b450b3aa39699e9bd10698a54759ddb8452c986d)

commit_message:
Don't quote {posargs} in tox.ini

Quotes around {posargs} cause the entire string to be combined into one
arg that gets passed to stestr. This prevents passing multiple args
(e.g. '--concurrency=16 some-regex')

Change-Id: I83986c645b21b3994c199c68419847d1507511de
Closes-Bug:  #1801454
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-refresh-config refs/changes/72/608972/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Skip the services with no endpoints when parsing service catalog

When parsing the service catalog to find the source, audit middleware
should skip over the services which have no endpoints instead of
assuming they will have at least one endpoint.

Change-Id: I287873e99338d95baaf20d52ecb3a43763a401fc
Closes-Bug: #1800017
(cherry picked from commit 6779838a242b222672721407cc320672ab24067a)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystonemiddleware refs/changes/21/614021/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - | [`bug 1800017 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystonemiddleware/+bug/1800017>`_] Fix audit middleware service catalog parsing for the scenario where a service does not contain any endpoints. In that case, we should just skip over that service.

commit_message:
Add ansible_python_interpreter to the inventory script

In order to be able to specify that we would like to use python2 or
python3 with the generated ansible inventory, the
tripleo-ansible-inventory script should take this as a parameter like it
does for the ansible ssh user.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/617793/
Change-Id: If70d046b3bdb2b0bd9fcc334e53f72e97b127cd7
Related-Blueprint: python3-support

commit_message:
Switch stable scenarios to voting

In master we have removed these from the gate as they are non-voting
because we plan on replacing them with standalone versions. However for
stable branches we will want to leave these as voting since they are
defined in the gate in the branch layout.

Change-Id: I7a859ac1db9206301df897553320fca70ea33980
Related-Bug: #1802144
(cherry picked from commit 3061e5d1bce513b3d58eae963722569b7f9bb50b)

commit_message:
Use TinyIPA deployment images

The coreos images do not appear to be functional.
I didn't spend too much time debugging why, but it
seemed like they hung on boot (but that may just be a
lack of console logging).

The TinyIPA images can deploy a server without issue.

TrivialFix
Change-Id: I58e4f951d4a3dd89e0784fd82d8a62dbba374f79

commit_message:
Use TinyIPA deployment images

The coreos images do not appear to be functional.
I didn't spend too much time debugging why, but it
seemed like they hung on boot (but that may just be a
lack of console logging).

The TinyIPA images can deploy a server without issue.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I97bc80e516e684fd24ad453d24c5d77316539fb0

commit_message:
Bugfix: Add datasource_name to an entity also on update

The vitrage_datasource_name property should
be added to every vertex, to allow its late
deletion by the consistency enforcer if
needed [1].
Until now this property was added only at
vertex creation. It should be added also at
vertex update.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/588219/

Change-Id: I49a0a008b18805cc247cbe1c7b9ccf156c4bae9f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/vitrage refs/changes/37/610337/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if entity.vertex and \ (entity.action == GraphAction.CREATE_ENTITY or entity.action == GraphAction.UPDATE_ENTITY): if datasource_name: entity.vertex.properties[VProps.VITRAGE_DATASOURCE_NAME] = \ datasource_name
deleted_lines: if entity.vertex and entity.action == GraphAction.CREATE_ENTITY: entity.vertex.properties[VProps.VITRAGE_DATASOURCE_NAME] = \ datasource_name

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/136136.html

commit_message:
Remove setup.py check from pep8 job

Using "python setup.py check -r -s" method of checking the package has
been deprecated with the new recommendation to build the sdist and
wheel, then running "twine check" against the output.

Luckily, there is already a job that covers this that only runs when the
README, setup.py, or setup.cfg files change, making running this in the
pep8 job redundant. This is covered by the test-release-openstack-python3
that is defined in the publish-to-pypi-python3 template.

More details can be found in this mailing list post:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/136136.html

Change-Id: I60ab96b2f69748e9fad65a73f168b414c14a857a
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add sync_db parameter in glance-api

As sync db is moved as a part of glance-api install, defining
sync_db parameter in glance::api

In the latest versions, it has been done during moving sync_db
parameter to glance-api and removing from glance-registry.
But backporting that change was changing major functionality in newton.

So, to avoid that, just adding sync_db in glance-api.

Change-Id: I209498033ea81571d45d9fbd69ff03e0155a9deb
Closes-Bug: 1731245
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-glance refs/changes/32/518832/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: Iad0076fbf34f699b9eb2134bae623793693534cb
Closes-Bug:  #1801657

commit_message:
Remove deprecated Ram/Disk filters in NovaSchedulerDefaultFilters

As reported in the related bug below and merged for the undercloud
with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/598167 the Ram/Disk filters
are deprecated since [1] so we should stop using them.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/596502/
Related-Bug: 1787910
Change-Id: Ib3585b4c04c974c34d61b868d0454df03c1a2aed
(cherry picked from commit 0ec9a3db94a6a0e09387f7d86860d93708c524db)

commit_message:
Noop out xinetd::service

With puppet 5.5.6, the xinetd::service being included by rsync::server
is force including the init.pp from xinetd. Since we don't actually want
any xinetd configurations in the container bits, we also need to noop
out xinetd::service along with the xinetd class.

Change-Id: I3075a852290d873915a61aae5fbe96202efb400f
Related-Blueprint: puppet5-support

With DVR routers, if a port is associated with a FloatingIP,
before it is used by a VM, the FloatingIP will be initially
started at the Network Node SNAT Namespace, since the port
is not bound to any host.

Then when the port is attached to a VM, the port gets its
host binding, and then the FloatingIP setup should be migrated
to the Compute host and the original FloatingIP in the Network

cleared by the agent.

This patch addresses the issue.

Change-Id: I55a16bcc0020087aa1abe76f5bc85cd64ccdaecd
Closes-Bug: #1796491
(cherry picked from commit cd0cc47a6ab0f7968a8c24e9d477909c45e4ae87)
'}]
commit_message:
DVR: Centralized FloatingIPs are not cleared after migration.

With DVR routers, if a port is associated with a FloatingIP,
before it is used by a VM, the FloatingIP will be initially
started at the Network Node SNAT Namespace, since the port
is not bound to any host.

Then when the port is attached to a VM, the port gets its
host binding, and then the FloatingIP setup should be migrated
to the Compute host and the original FloatingIP in the Network
Node SNAT Namespace should be cleared.

But the original FloatingIP setup in SNAT Namespace was not
cleared by the agent.

This patch addresses the issue.

Change-Id: I55a16bcc0020087aa1abe76f5bc85cd64ccdaecd
Closes-Bug: #1796491
(cherry picked from commit cd0cc47a6ab0f7968a8c24e9d477909c45e4ae87)

commit_message:
Improve cinder::nova support for auth_type password

Add ability to configure the [nova] settings required when the auth_type
is password. This allows cinder to access the nova API as a privileged
user.

Change-Id: Ia357ea41f8472d47e266d853f120a14b767e880d
(cherry picked from commit 05d6b0851fea9da6e057cef295b39a77d1b6cca3)

commit_message:
Default PUPPET_MAJ_VERSION to 5

Shouldn't use puppet 4 when running tests manually
while testing. This is last cycle we will support
puppet 4.

Change-Id: I6edb56a1fc85559e1f96cb93781e52e4e99ff889

commit_message:
Update port pool with non-default values

Change the test to work with the namespaces, so it can run
non sequentually
Update port pool on newly created namespace with non-default values
Create new pods in that namespace
Check that port pool is working as before
Perform connectivity test between pods

Depends-On: Ic0dac5075418ec71e3beca48fdd811c5df1ff467
Change-Id: I13cca6f77c66e88788365cc7bf94ddcfa787c167
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr-tempest-plugin refs/changes/21/603121/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: KURYR_CONTROLLER = 'kuryr-controller' if pod.metadata.name.startswith(KURYR_CONTROLLER)] def restart_kuryr_controller(self): kube_system_pods = self.get_pod_name_list( namespace=CONF.kuryr_kubernetes.kube_system_namespace) for kuryr_pod_name in kube_system_pods: if kuryr_pod_name.startswith(KURYR_CONTROLLER): self.delete_pod( pod_name=kuryr_pod_name, body={"kind": "DeleteOptions", "apiVersion": "v1", "gracePeriodSeconds": 0}, namespace=CONF.kuryr_kubernetes.kube_system_namespace) # make sure the kuryr pod was deleted self.wait_for_pod_status( kuryr_pod_name, namespace=CONF.kuryr_kubernetes.kube_system_namespace) # Check that new kuryr-controller is up and running kube_system_pods = self.get_pod_name_list( namespace=CONF.kuryr_kubernetes.kube_system_namespace) for kube_system_pod in kube_system_pods: if kube_system_pod.startswith(KURYR_CONTROLLER): self.wait_for_pod_status( kube_system_pod, namespace=CONF.kuryr_kubernetes.kube_system_namespace, pod_status='Running', retries=120) # Wait until kuryr-controller pools are reloaded, i.e., # kuryr-controller is ready pod_readiness_retries = 30 while not self.get_pod_readiness( kube_system_pod, namespace=CONF.kuryr_kubernetes.kube_system_namespace): time.sleep(1) pod_readiness_retries -= 1 if pod_readiness_retries == 0: raise lib_exc.TimeoutException()

subject: Certificate changes should restart services
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-11-15 12:33:15.000000000', 'files': ['releasenotes/notes/restart-service-certificate-b4000c445374129c.yaml', 'manifests/certificates.pp', 'spec/classes/octavia_certificates_spec.rb', 'manifests/deps.pp'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-octavia/commit/ad4d9560158c6a553608a69d259f784162f46e8f', 'message': 'Certificate changes should restart services

Certificate changes or path changes in octavia::certificate
should notify the octavia::service::begin anchor so that services
are refreshed otherwise for example octavia-worker will not use a
new certificate.

Change-Id: Ie03cfedccc6a675976688a944b1ee91a0a9f55f1

'}]
commit_message:
Certificate changes should restart services

Certificate changes or path changes in octavia::certificate
should notify the octavia::service::begin anchor so that services
are refreshed otherwise for example octavia-worker will not use a
new certificate.

Change-Id: Ie03cfedccc6a675976688a944b1ee91a0a9f55f1
(cherry picked from commit ab310a65e359a569672fbb60bab5d1403714a303)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-octavia refs/changes/43/618143/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Changes in certificate or folders will restart services. File<| tag == 'octavia-certificate' |> ~> Anchor['octavia::service::begin']

commit_message:
Add framework for octavia-status upgrade check

This commit adds the functionality of octavia-status CLI for performing
upgrade checks as part of the Stein cycle upgrade-checkers goal.
It only includes a sample check which must be replaced by real checks in
future.

Change-Id: I8b6d134b0bf5b5c82a19177fed6145ef8aaf7507
Story: 2003657
Task: 26146

commit_message:
Improve logs when hard linking images fails

When hard linking images fail in ironic the logs doesn't have
enough related path information to resolve the underlying cause
of the exception.

Change-Id: I3331c4eca2deb9383f448f1efa93cbef53019f9c
Story: #2004303
Task: #27863

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-11-14 16:02:40.000000000', 'files': ['tripleoclient/tests/v1/undercloud/test_undercloud.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient/commit/ba9e16639fab485e63909a1036fab22901faa235', 'message': 'Mock configuration load in unit tests

Previously if you had an undercloud.conf in your home directory, the
tests would load it and use values from it as the defaults for the tests
if they were not overridden in the tests. This could lead to incorrect
failures. This change mocks the config loading out from the install and

Closes-Bug: #1803387
'}]
commit_message:
Mock configuration load in unit tests

Previously if you had an undercloud.conf in your home directory, the
tests would load it and use values from it as the defaults for the tests
if they were not overridden in the tests. This could lead to incorrect
failures. This change mocks the config loading out from the install and
upgrade actions for the undercloud to prevent this loading.

Change-Id: I57a12f0151bc65f26a7e880b0f1f367a7711ead9
Closes-Bug: #1803387

Update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0.  Update to
reflect reality, which should help with local running of constraints
targets.

commit_message:
Update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0.  Update to
reflect reality, which should help with local running of constraints
targets.

Change-Id: I268870bd9b00d86227fcc61fe65fd8c301e92c1e
Related-Bug: 1801465

https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

commit_message:
use payloads for SEGMENT BEFORE_DELETE callbacks

This patch switches over to the payload style of callbacks for SEGMENT
BEFORE_DELETE events. It does so by using the publish callback function
with DBEventPayload payloads. Corresponding listener callbacks are
updated where necessary.

NeutronLibImpact

Change-Id: I64031129ad458d4468a316a9385288ced091d333

deleted_lines: context, segment, for_net_delete=False): if for_net_delete: with db_api.context_manager.reader.using(context): segment_id = segment['id'] query = context.session.query(models_v2.Port.id)

commit_message:
Fix connection between 2 dvr routers

In case when 2 dvr routers are connected to each other with
tenant network, those routers needs to be always deployed
on same compute nodes.
So this patch changes dvr routers scheduler that it will create
dvr router on each host on which there are vms or other dvr routers
connected to same subnets.

Co-Authored-By: Swaminathan Vasudevan <SVasudevan@suse.com>

Closes-Bug: #1786272

Conflicts:
    neutron/agent/l3/agent.py
    neutron/db/l3_dvr_db.py
    neutron/tests/unit/agent/l3/test_agent.py

Change-Id: I579c2522f8aed2b4388afacba34d9ffdc26708e3
(cherry picked from commit 5018d702415a6f056ff54d95447c5031e7e7d9b9)
(cherry picked from commit b127433f38d69fee48f89e9fc6b4a14dba8e9352)

commit_message:
[CI] Switch Xenial tempest jobs to Bionic Beaver

This change specifically ignores the grenade
job (manila-grenade), which is pending conversion
to zuulv3 because we need a way to set the default
python3 interpreter when running on Bionic Beaver.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/605291/
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/605242/
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/605810/
Change-Id: Ic49d4ac5ac36dd3b3d909941434b2d2f104a10b9
